paragraphs.text:
%md # Introduction: Part I of Splice Machine Training for Developers This class is recommended for query writers, ETL processors, and developers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand the topics in this section, you need to have experience with SQL, and some programming experience with Python or Scala. You can expect to spend 1-2 hours completing this class. Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and many of the notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web. This is the sequence of notebooks in our *Splice Machine Beginning Developer's* class:
1. If you've not already done so, please visit our General Introduction to Splice Machine notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. The Notebook Basics notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this class.
3. Before learning how to import data into your Splice Machine database, use The Preparing Data for Import notebook to learn how to copy the data you'll be importing to an S3 bucket.
4. The Importing Data notebook walks you through importing data into your Splice Machine database from flat files that are stored in S3.
5. The Running Queries notebook introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
6. The Tuning Queries for Performance notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, including: collecting statistics, compacting, creating primary keys and indexes, and strategies for joining tables.
7. The Using the Database Console UI notebook introduces the dashboard you can use to monitor queries sent to the Spark engine; this allows you to follow the progress of queries running in Spark, monitor GC usage, and terminate queries when necessary.
8. The Using Explain and Hints notebook teaches you how to understand query execution plans and how to use hints to influence execution plans.

msg.data:
Introduction: Part I of Splice Machine Training for Developers

This class is recommended for query writers, ETL processors, and developers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand the topics in this section, you need to have experience with SQL, and some programming experience with Python or Scala. You can expect to spend 1-2 hours completing this class.

Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and many of the notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web.

This is the sequence of notebooks in our Splice Machine Beginning Developer’s class:

1. If you've not already done so, please visit our General Introduction to Splice Machine notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. The Notebook Basics notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this class.
3. Before learning how to import data into your Splice Machine database, use The Preparing Data for Import notebook to learn how to copy the data you'll be importing to an S3 bucket.
4. The Importing Data notebook walks you through importing data into your Splice Machine database from flat files that are stored in S3.
5. The Running Queries notebook introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
6. The Tuning Queries for Performance notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, including: collecting statistics, compacting, creating primary keys and indexes, and strategies for joining tables.
7. The Using the Database Console UI notebook introduces the dashboard you can use to monitor queries sent to the Spark engine; this allows you to follow the progress of queries running in Spark, monitor GC usage, and terminate queries when necessary.
8. The Using Explain and Hints notebook teaches you how to understand query execution plans and how to use hints to influence execution plans.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Where to Go Next
Please start this class with the [*Notebook Basics*](/#/notebook/2DV36AEJ2) notebook for a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks.
